The Hudson Bay Company (HBC) was a major player in the early mapping and exploration of the Arctic region. The HBC was founded in 1670 and operated as a fur trading company in Canada. In the late 17th and early 18th centuries, the company began to explore the Arctic region in search of new fur-trading opportunities.

The HBC played a key role in mapping the Arctic coastline and river systems. The company's explorers, traders, and surveyors produced detailed maps of the region, which were used by other explorers and scientists in later expeditions.

The HBC also played a significant role in the exploration and discovery of new trade routes through the Arctic. The company established trading posts and forts along the coast, which helped to open up new trade routes and facilitate the exchange of goods between Europe and North America.

Overall, the HBC played a crucial role in the early mapping and exploration of the Arctic region, and its contributions have had a lasting impact on our understanding of this remote and challenging part of the world.
